desc: Still learning how to work in the lab, we started two new joints.  With 'get down,' we just wanted to make a funky party jam.  The rhyme content reflects this theme. With 'no time' though, we wanted to touch on cat's fakin the funk...a topic a little more serious. We felt the contrast between the two songs would make for a dope and balanced 12 inch. This single also features our first piece of cover art! Word.

Still learning how to work in the lab, we started two new joints.  With 'get down,' we just wanted to make a funky party jam.  The rhyme content reflects this theme. With 'no time' though, we wanted to touch on cat's fakin the funk...a topic a little more serious. We felt the contrast between the two songs would make for a dope and balanced 12 inch. This single also features our first piece of cover art! Word.

Once again, we\'re in a super-heated closet laying vocals.  \'The difference\' is a funky little hip-hop cut with Profile flexing on the mic, all the while letting listeners know why we\'re here: \'to make a difference\'.  With OC on the chorus, you got the message.  \'Yes ya\'ll\' is a funked out ill piano loop that added another flavor to the Sp spectrum.  And with Biz on the help-out, you can\'t go wrong.

Surreal is no joke, and this lead off single proves it.  Funky rhymes, check.  Precise flow, check.  Intelligent bars wrapped in a fly oldschool capsule, check.  What more can you ask for then two potent joints that permeate freshness?  Well Surreal\'s answer would be \'a whole fly album.\'  And he can do that too.  But this single was the funky calm before the storm, and damn if it ain\'t lovely.  \'Just getting started\' sports a boomed-out baseline in conjunction with dirty drums.  And with some assistance by a scratched Diamond D, Surreal let\'s everyone know the time: this is just the beginning ya\'ll.  On the flip-side is the sip an exotic drink and vibe to the latin percussion sound of \'place to be\', with it\'s rolling horn and bassline double-teaming your eardrums into a samba frenzy.  Where exactly is the place to be, you ask?  Wherever Surreal and the Sp\'s happen to be.  Ill leadoff single to the True Indeed lp.

It had been a while since the Evening With the SP\'s LP, and we were hearing from lots of cats who were interested in the original 12\'s we dropped with Profile in the beginning.  The idea came together to compile all of the original 12\' releases along with other cuts that we didn\'t release from that time period.  It was actually a small trip through memory lane going through old DAT and ADAT tapes, pulling up old archives.  This LP is a good time capsule from the SP lab during those times

When we approached Yesh and Ken Boog about a remix, they thought it would be dope to do part II of the original cut with a different feel, rather than just a remix.  We agreed, and began sifting through beats.  The vibes on this cut tell a story in and of themselves.  The 5 Minutes joint was a heavy favorite from \'An Evening with the Sound Providers\' LP.  We thought it would be the move to put a remix single together and it was a prime candidate.  The Procussions get extra busy on this cut, and the beat takes it to a new funky new place.

Upon completion of the \'an evening with...\' lp,  Jay and Soulo refuse to take time off to chill.  Next up is two joints with a Virginia native named Blest.  This time around a more rugged Sp sound emerges to compliment the flame spitting mc.  \'The Blessing\' is an intense barrage of heavy lyrics, drums and scratches.  The taunting scratch outro lets listeners know Blest isn\'t joking.  \'Who Said What\' rounds of this wax platter, with Blest\'s commentary on folks who just can\'t stop talking about people trying to achieve.  Two dope joints make for an ill introduction to a nice mc, as well as continuing the relentless track record of funky Soundprovider productions.

2nd single of the \'Evening with...\' lp featuring the always soulful, and incredibly talented, Asheru of Unspoken Heard.  For Old Time\'s Sake is a bouncy vibe ride that touches on the inspiration that fuels the music we make.  Class is definitely in session as Asheru flows precisely, and let\'s you know the foundation he stands firmly upon.  On the b-side we have a reworked version of Maspyke\'s \'The Throwback\'.  Always striving to give you more, Jay & Soulo remix an already fresh joint and give it a totally different feel.  A chopped guitar and cascading flutes lay a darker foundation to Tabkleek and Hanif\'s pinpoint rhyme lesson.  Once again, the beat scientist\'s continue to deliver quality.

This is the lead single off of the Sp\'s long overdue first lp, \'an Evening With The Sound Providers\'.  On the A-side we have the talented Little Brother crew kicking science about the here today gone tomorrow cycle of hip-hop fame.  Funky guitar licks and light keys lay a buttery foundation to the trio\'s cautionary tale.  On the B-side we have the rediculously slept on, yet unbelievably fresh Maspyke, drop three 16 bar lessons. Think about it, Talk about it, BE ABOUT IT!  Wise words in conjunction with a fly piano make, as Lyte & Pos K would say, a good combination.

aSide: An Evening With the Sound Providers LP
desc:
This album was a long time coming, but once our conducter\'s were ready to begin and embark on a full length opus, they ran into a problem. Having slimmed down to a two man production crew, Jay and Soulo were faced with the obstacle of not having a vocalist to rock over thier tracks.  On the other side of the coin though, back at the Soundpro lab, new beats were being stacked up daily.  The dilemna arose: How could they still get busy and drop a dope lp, minus a lead mc?  Well, never the type to duck a challenge (or sit back and NOT make music), the beat fiends racked thier brains in an effort to find a way two producer\'s could put together a memorable lp.  Could they do it?  Was it even possible?
Like Kris in 88\', it had to get done... \'by all means necessary\'.

The three newjacks dilligently try their hand at creating music.  This was our first time in the lab, and this record was a 100% experiment for the three of us.  If the music was wack, we\'d never try it again.  Countless sessions later (that\'s a big understatement) we felt we had something that was solid enough for people to hear.  Surprisingly, a few folk\'s were feeling the vibe.  So we decided to try it again, and the SP\'s were born!

Recording a joint with Grap Luva was probably the hypest experience so far for us.  We pretty much idolized the cat for years, and then all the sudden he\'s loungin in our apartment listening to beats and penning rhymes.  We came up with the song title on the spot, Grap wrote and kicked his verse, and then we all sat back with smiles on our faces.  That song came together more effortlessly than anything we\'d ever done... everything just fell into place.  With the energetically fly \'fresh rhymes\' rounding off the b-side, you have a 12 inch made BY hip-hop fanatics, FOR hip-hop fanatics.  Quality single, legendary guest mc... San Diego is on the map

This was just a little something that we threw out there as a promo item, Jay on one side, and Soulo on the other.  We always wanted to drop a 45, and so we each just grabbed a random disk, loaded it up and mixed it down.  A small pressing of funk for the serious Sp collector.

True Indeed started as a single, that turned into an EP, that became an LP.  We just kept recording more and more, and the cuts seemed to be fresher and fresher.  Soulo or Jay would come up with a new beat, or Surreal would have a new concept.  Someone would stumble across a new sample, and next thing you know we\'d have a new cut on our hands.  The addition of Surreal on this record really brought about a new prolific nature to the SP\'s.  Things started happening at a rapid rate.  From the Intro to the end this is 100 percent boom-bap hip-hop technology.  Did we make a dope record?  TRUE INDEED!!!!

Not ones to play the back, the sp\'s hit the labs once again to put together a new joint.  \'Nuff Said.  Hip Hop the way is was always meant to be made.  Surreal had the original idea for the cuts, and the way Soulo hooks them up sounds so Hip Hop.  It would be difficult to go wrong with such a fresh hook.  Surreal is getting looser and looser as time goes on.  Extra, Extra dope joint
